content: U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission Release# 09-151 12 March 2009 http://www.cpsc.gov/cpscpub/prerel/prhtml09/09151.html Washington, DC The US Consumer Product Safety Commission, in cooperation with the firm named below, today announced a voluntary recall of the following consumer product. Consumers should stop using recalled products immediately unless otherwise directed. Name of Product: Kidde XL Fire Extinguishers Units: About 167,000 Distributor: Walter Kidde Portable Equipmenty, Inc., of Mebane, N.N. Hazard: The pressurized cylinders in the recalled fire extinguishers could lose pressure and fail to operate. In the event of a fire, this failure could put a consumer and property at risk. Incidents/Injuries: None Reported Description: This recall involves the Kidde XL Fire extinguishers with model numbers: FX340SC, FX340H, FX340GW, XL5MR, FX210R, FX340SC-2, FX210W, XL2.5TCZ-4, E-340-3 and with the manufacturers dates between October 2007 and April 2008. "Kidde" and the model number can be found on the label on the front of the extinguisher. The manufacture year is on the bottom of the extinguisher. If your extinguisher is one of listed model numbers and is marked with the year '07' or '08'. Sold at: Department, home, and hardware stores nationwide from October 2007 through April 2008 for about $35. Manufacturered in: Mexico Remedy: Consumers should immediately inspect the pressure guage. If it points to the 'red zone', contact Kidde to receive a free replacement extinguisher. If the guage is not in the 'red zone', but you have questions about an extinguisher within the listed model numbers, please contact Kidde for additional information. Consumer Contact: For additional information, contact Kidde at (888)345-4407 between 8 a.m. and 5 p.m. Eastern time, Monday through Friday or visit the firm's web site at "www.Kidde.com" +++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++ I have dealt with these extinguishers before in the course of my line of work these past few years. They are junk! A couple of years before, Kidde issued a large recall of their 10# ABC fire extinguishers due to a factory defective failure connected to the cylinder neck welded to the cylinder. The weld was poor, and resulted in loss of pressure. This latest recall covers the 2.5 and 5 pound extinguishers. This pressure failure may be due to any of the following: Defective Guage, Defective O-Ring, Defective Check Stem. These extinguishers are normally found in the homes, as well as newly-opened businesses, when the contractor buys them 'in bulk', installs them so said business can qualify for their "Certificate of Occupancy". I DO NOT advise having these above in your home or garage. Contact me thru my profile if you have any questions. This message has been edited. Last edited by: Hoffy1951, Mon 23 March 2009 04:48 PM

title: Kidde Recalls to Replace Fire Extinguishers Due to Failure to Operate

content: quote: Originally posted by stillkit: quote: Manufacturered in: Mexico There's the problem right there. Kit... Kinda, Sorta... There have been inheritant problems with the manufacturer for quite some time...even before their manufacturing operations shifted to Mexico. When Kidde initially released certain 2.5#, 5# and 10# extinguishers back in the mid-late 90s, the check stems were made from plastic, and had the consistency of a bent "Q tip", and, the pressure guage housing was plastic as well. As now, the valve assembly for the 2.5# to the 20#, for the most part, is made from a hard nylon plastic that will break, if not shatter if dropped. Some models' valve assemblies are made from metal; but, still are problematic. A large majority of the 2.5# and 5# cylinders are made from 'spun aluminum'...and when coupled with the plastic valve assemblies...JUNK! The valve threads will strip if these are serviced improperly, and not reassembled properly (screwed on the first time). These are pressurized at either 100 or 195 PSI... Don't get me wrong about the company as a whole...they manufacture other quality Fire Safety/Prevention devices...
quote: Originally posted by stillkit: quote: Manufacturered in: Mexico There's the problem right there.

As now, the valve assembly for the 2.5# to the 20#, for the most part, is made from a hard nylon plastic that will break, if not shatter if dropped. Some models' valve assemblies are made from metal; but, still are problematic. A large majority of the 2.5# and 5# cylinders are made from 'spun aluminum'...and when coupled with the plastic valve assemblies...JUNK! Don't get me wrong about the company as a whole...they manufacture other quality Fire Safety/Prevention devices...
